subject: Re: [junit] Runtime arguments to be submitted to MyTestCase
msgSnippet: ... Let me explain what the product is! It s a unit/interoperability testing framework for protocol implementations. It has to test whether a protocol
messageBody:
"J. B. Rainsberger" wrote:
>
> On 2002-06-08 at 17:11 NOUSHI Reda wrote:
>
> >"J. B. Rainsberger" wrote:
> >>
> >> On 2002-06-07 at 16:30 NOUSHI Reda wrote:
> >>
> >> >i have the problem shown in the subject. My class has to be told
> some
> >> >argumets before it can work.
> >>
> >> Is there any reason those can't be parameters to the class'
> >> constructor? Your tests can then either take that information from
> >> properties files or hardcode the parameters to the class you're
> >> testing.
>
> >But the class constructors are used AFAIK internally, in the
> TestRunner.
> >I have to make TestRunner pass its commandline args to each of my
> >testcases. That is not in the contract that
> >binds TestRunner and the TestCase classes.
>
> Now I am confused. Which "classes": the classes under test? or the test
> case classes? TestCases generally do not need parameters. External
> data, yes; parameters, well, I've never needed to do it.
>
> >> >I can technically change the junit code to do waht I want, but the
> >> >problem is that I'm working in a proprietary software (I did all I
> >> could
> >> >to et it open sourced...), I think that legally all my changes to
> the
> >> >junit soft has to be published in GPL.
> >>
> >> Why? Do you plan to ship JUnit with your product?
>
> >My TestCases inherits from junit.framework.TestCase, so I have to ship
> >junit unchanged with my product.
>
> Why? Do you plan to ship your test cases with your product?
Let me explain what the product is!
It's a unit/interoperability testing framework for protocol
implementations.
It has to test whether a protocol implementation respects the protocol
specification. This is done by transforming what we call a 'test
scenario', which is a suite of requests and responses, into, say,
MyTestCase a class that inherits from junit.framework.TestCase.
Until then, no prob! But the way we adress our implementations is by
using CORBA. So the args are needed to initialize the ORB. It is true
that I can use the properties file, and that's what I'll do.
About the shipping, I need to run junit as it is my frontend and
MyTestCase inherits from a junit class. That's why I ship junit with the
software.
Hope it's clear for now!

You can take a look at 2 threads in junit mailing list, called:
Re: [junit] How to create data-driven tests? II!
and
[junit] Re: How to create data-driven tests? II!
It shows more about the 'product'.

Reda
